isomorphic_concept.definition: Isomorphic patterns are functional structures that repeat with identical causal topology across different scales, from subatomic to cosmic, allowing direct comparison and pattern detection based on observable mechanisms.
handling_rules: Map patterns to 8 scales plus a principle; entries must be concrete and observable.
Validate for complete coverage; flag gaps as incomplete.
Support sub-categories for compound patterns to maintain cleanliness.
Export as lean JSON for use in other modules; no external references.
Apply evaluation methods to validate patterns; use contradictions_ledger to track inconsistencies.

evaluation_methods.name: Completeness Validation
evaluation_methods.description: Iterate through each category and sub-category; check that all required scales have non-empty string mappings; flag incomplete entries.

evaluation_methods.name: Consistency Alignment
evaluation_methods.description: For each category, verify logical alignment between mappings and principle; flag misalignments or forced fits.

evaluation_methods.name: Isomorphism Scoring
evaluation_methods.description: Represent causal topology of each mapping as a graph; compute similarity scores (e.g., via graph edit distance) between graphs across scales; score >0.8 indicates strong isomorphism.

evaluation_methods.name: Gap Flagging
evaluation_methods.description: Identify scales with weak or absent mappings; log for refinement in contradictions_ledger.

evaluation_methods.name: Contradiction Detection
evaluation_methods.description: Scan for inconsistencies (e.g., mappings contradicting principle); catalog in ledger with source, conflict, justification, scope, and branches.

evaluation_methods.name: Fixed Point Check
evaluation_methods.description: Recursively apply evaluation methods to the module's output until no changes occur, confirming stability.

isomorphic_mapping.definition: A comprehensive set of structural, functional, and conceptual analogies between biological brains (human/neural systems) and artificial neural networks (ANNs/deep learning models), derived from extensive research papers and sites. These mappings highlight similarities in architecture, learning, processing, and dynamics, while noting limitations for coherence. Sources include arXiv, Nature, PubMed, PMC, Wikipedia, and others (e.g., arXiv:2306.04449, Nature s41598-021-84813-6, PMC articles on neuromorphic computing).
handling_rules: Mappings are based on observable mechanisms and research findings; focus on direct analogies without overclaiming identity.
Each category includes biological description, artificial counterpart, key similarity, and supporting sources/examples.
Aim for maximal coverage: 30+ categories compiled from searches.
Coherence maintained by grouping into themes (e.g., structure, learning, dynamics); analogies are bidirectional where applicable.

human-ai_categories.biological: Neuron with dendrites (input receivers), soma (integration), axon (output transmitter). Fires action potentials based on threshold.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Artificial neuron/perceptron with inputs, summation function, activation (e.g., sigmoid/ReLU), and output.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both integrate weighted inputs and apply a non-linear threshold to produce output signals.

human-ai_categories.biological: Synapses as junctions between neurons, with neurotransmitters modulating strength.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Weights/connections between nodes, adjustable during training.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both represent adjustable strengths of influence between units, enabling information flow.

human-ai_categories.biological: Hebbian learning: 'Cells that fire together wire together'; long-term potentiation (LTP) strengthens connections.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Backpropagation and gradient descent adjust weights based on error signals.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both mechanisms allow adaptation by strengthening or weakening connections over time/experience.

human-ai_categories.biological: Homeostatic mechanisms maintain firing rate stability (e.g., fast rate detectors).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Regularization techniques (e.g., L2 norm) prevent overfitting and stabilize training.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both ensure network stability during learning to avoid runaway excitation or silence.
human-ai_categories.sources: PLoS Comput Biol e1003330; Frontiers in Neural Circuits (2020)

human-ai_categories.biological: Layered cortex: Early visual areas detect edges, higher areas recognize objects.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Deep layers: Convolutional layers extract features hierarchically (edges to objects).
human-ai_categories.similarity: Progressive abstraction from simple to complex representations.
human-ai_categories.sources: Nature s41562-025-02318-y; Scientific Reports srep27755; MIT News (2022)

human-ai_categories.biological: Recurrent connections and top-down modulation (e.g., attention).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs/LSTMs) with loops for sequence processing.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both enable context-dependent processing and memory retention.

human-ai_categories.biological: Dendrites perform local computations and integration.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Dendritic-inspired ANNs add sub-computations for precision and efficiency.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Local processing enhances robustness and parameter efficiency.

human-ai_categories.biological: Discrete action potentials (spikes) for efficient signaling.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) use discrete events for energy-efficient computation.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Event-based processing reduces continuous computation overhead.

human-ai_categories.biological: Ultralow energy per spike (e.g., 10^-17 J).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Neuromorphic chips (e.g., IBM TrueNorth) mimic low-power asynchronous events.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both prioritize sparse, event-driven computation over constant activity.

human-ai_categories.biological: Chemicals (e.g., dopamine) modulate neuron excitability.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Hyperparameters or adaptive learning rates modulate training dynamics.
human-ai_categories.similarity: External signals tune responsiveness and learning speed.
human-ai_categories.sources: PMC: PMC12480988; Wiley Adv Funct Mater (2023)

human-ai_categories.biological: Short-term (hippocampus) and long-term (cortex) via synaptic changes.
human-ai_categories.artificial: LSTM gates for short-term, embeddings for long-term patterns.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Mechanisms for retaining and consolidating information over time.

human-ai_categories.biological: Brain predicts sensory input and minimizes prediction error.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Autoencoders or generative models minimize reconstruction loss.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Both optimize by reducing discrepancy between prediction and reality.

human-ai_categories.biological: Selective focus via top-down signals.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Attention layers (e.g., Transformers) weight relevant inputs.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Prioritizes salient information in processing streams.

human-ai_categories.biological: Balances new learning with memory retention (e.g., synaptic scaling).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Elastic Weight Consolidation prevents catastrophic forgetting.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Mechanisms to adapt without overwriting prior knowledge.

human-ai_categories.biological: Oscillatory patterns in neural circuits (e.g., theta waves).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Recurrent loops in RNNs for temporal dependencies.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Handles sequences and timing through cycles.

human-ai_categories.biological: Intrinsic excitability modulated by ion channels.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Bias terms in neurons shift activation thresholds.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Adjusts baseline sensitivity without input changes.

human-ai_categories.biological: Evolutionary and experiential fine-tuning.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) over data.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Iterative adjustment to minimize errors or maximize fitness.

human-ai_categories.biological: Sparse neural firing for efficiency.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Sparsity regularization in ANNs.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Reduces redundancy by activating few units per input.

human-ai_categories.biological: Specialized brain regions (e.g., visual cortex).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Modular networks or sub-networks for tasks.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Division of labor for complex functions.

human-ai_categories.biological: Redundancy and unary coding for robustness.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Dropout or ensemble methods for fault tolerance.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Handles noise or failures gracefully.

human-ai_categories.biological: Skill transfer across domains (e.g., motor learning).
human-ai_categories.artificial: Pre-trained models fine-tuned on new tasks.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Leverages prior knowledge for new adaptations.

human-ai_categories.biological: Mental simulation and dreaming.
human-ai_categories.artificial: GANs or VAEs generating new data.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Creates internal representations or samples.

human-ai_categories.biological: Integration over time in sensory processing.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Convolution over time in video models.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Accumulates evidence across sequences.

human-ai_categories.biological: GABAergic neurons suppress activity.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Negative weights or inhibition layers.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Balances excitation to prevent overload.

human-ai_categories.biological: Analog, parallel brain computation.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Neuromorphic chips (e.g., Loihi) with analog elements.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Hardware emulation for brain-like efficiency.

human-ai_categories.biological: Self-organization in development.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Autoencoders learning features without labels.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Discovers patterns from raw data.

human-ai_categories.biological: Dopamine-driven reinforcement.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Reinforcement Learning with rewards.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Strengthens actions leading to positive outcomes.

human-ai_categories.biological: Billions of synapses for flexibility.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Overparameterized models generalize well.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Excess capacity enables robust learning.

human-ai_categories.biological: Consciousness from neural interactions.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Emergent capabilities in large models (e.g., in-context learning).
human-ai_categories.similarity: Complex phenomena from simple rules.

human-ai_categories.biological: Brain size correlates with intelligence across species.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Performance scales with model size and data.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Larger systems yield better capabilities.

human-ai_categories.biological: Robust to synaptic noise and cell death.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Robust to dropout or perturbations.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Graceful degradation under damage.

human-ai_categories.biological: Context-modulated neural responses.
human-ai_categories.artificial: Embeddings capture contextual meanings.
human-ai_categories.similarity: Represents information relative to surroundings.
